into educational structures. Programs, however good, could also not succeed,
if transmitted over facilities which were technically such as to discourage
viewership, In some areas deadlocks with labor threatened to delay or prevent
further development. Courses and workshops to train people in all phases of
operation of educational station operation, and research, were needed. For
unless the people on whom educational television rested were to be capable
and professionally trained and welded into the nucleus of a profession, with
a sense of unity and “esprit de corps," the fate of radio in education might
well be repeated.
A central placement or employment office was also called for, to assist
stations to find the best possible personnel for a new field, and to encourage
interest by well-qualified people in careers in educational television.
■With the delegation and assignment to the other organizations men¬
tioned above of those specialized functions listed, perhaps too briefly, the
NAEB, the only membership-based association in the group, was left with a
broad field of responsibilities which were in many respects less dramatic and
less conspicuous than most of the others. The present report sets forth how
the NAEB has attempted to fulfill this role, and gratefully acknowledges the
invaluable assistance provided for this effort from Ford funds.
During the course of the seven years covered by this report, the NAEB
